sols_html:
The critical points of a multivariable function \(f(x,y)\) are the values of \((x,y)\) where the following conditions are both simultaneously true:

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{cases} \frac{\partial f}{\partial x}(x,y) = 0 \\ \frac{\partial f}{\partial y}(x,y) = 0 \end{cases}\end{aligned}\]

Since \(\displaystyle f(x,y) = xye^{-2x-y}\), the above conditions become:

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{cases} ye^{-2x - y} -2xye^{-2x - y} = 0 \\ xe^{-2x - y} - xye^{-2x - y} = 0 \end{cases}\end{aligned}\]

To solve these equations, we begin by factoring the left-hand sides, giving us

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{cases} y(1 - 2x)e^{-2x - y} = 0 \\ x(1 - y)e^{-2x - y} = 0 \end{cases}\end{aligned}\]

Since the exponential function is never zero, the equations above are equivalent to

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{cases} y(1 - 2x) = 0 \quad &(1) \\ x(1 - y) = 0. \quad &(2) \end{cases}\end{aligned}\]

We now proceed to determine the values of \((x,y)\) such both Eq. (1) and (2) hold. The solutions to Eq. (1) are \(y = 0\) and \(x = 1/2\). We take each of these solutions and plug them into Eq. (2).

If \(y = 0\), then Eq. (2) becomes:

\[\begin{aligned} x(1-0) = 0 \quad \rightarrow \quad x = 0.\end{aligned}\]

Hence one of the critical points is \((x,y) = (0,0)\).

If \(x = 1/2\), then Eq. (2) becomes:

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{2}(1 - y) = 0 \quad \rightarrow \quad y = 1.\end{aligned}\]

So, another critical point is \((x,y) = (1/2,1)\).

Therefore, the critical points of \(f\) are \({\color{blue}\displaystyle (x,y) = (0,0),\left(\frac{1}{2},1\right).}\)
